units.title: Machine-vision based cell detection and co-encapsulation
units.text: DisCo depends on machine-vision to actively detect cells and coordinate their capture in droplets, allowing for continuous operation and enabling free per-run scaling and serial processing of samples.
units.rationale: Describes the core detection and capture step of the protocol.

units.title: Impedance-based input cell counting
units.text: we quantified the number of input cells using impedance measurements, which enabled accurate counting of the number of input cells as validated by microscopy (Extended Data Fig. 2f).
units.rationale: Provides a quantitative method for counting cells before encapsulation.

units.title: Cell capture efficiency assessment
units.text: We found that on average, 91.4% of all droplets contain a cell and a bead, and only 1.7% contain an independent cell doublet (Fig. 1f).
units.rationale: Reports the efficiency of cell‑bead co‑encapsulation.

units.title: Processing low‑input cell numbers
units.text: DisCo efficiently captures cells from low-input samples. As a first benchmarking experiment, we set out to determine the cell capture efficiency and the bead and cell co-encapsulation purity of DisCo.
units.rationale: Defines the experimental setup for evaluating low‑input performance.

units.title: Species‑mixing validation experiment
units.text: we performed a species mixing experiment of human embryonic kidney (HEK) 293T and murine immortalized brown pre-adipocyte (IBA) cells.
units.rationale: Validates cell identification and barcode merging using mixed species.

units.title: Microvalve flow‑control implementation
units.text: Implementation of Quake-style microvalves to facilitate flow control during operation; the development of a machine-vision-based approach utilizing subsequent image subtraction for blob detection to move particles into the target region of interest with 95.9% of particles placed in the ~200-μm-wide region.
units.rationale: Describes hardware control that ensures precise particle positioning.

units.title: Droplet volume regulation via dropleting valve
units.text: the pressurization of the dropleting valve to enable accurate control of droplet volume (Extended Data Fig. 1e and Supplementary Video 1).
units.rationale: Ensures consistent droplet size for downstream library preparation.

units.title: Time‑dependent quality assessment
units.text: We assessed time-dependent effects on the quality of the single cell data by analyzing HEK 293T cells that were loaded on our system (at 22 °C (room temperature)) for 0–20, 20–40 and 40–60 min.
units.rationale: Evaluates how processing time influences data quality.

units.title: Throughput measurement at different cell concentrations
units.text: 90% at around 200 cells per hour for a cell concentration of 2 cells per μl (Fig. 1g). At a higher cell concentration of 20 cells per μl, the processing speed could be increased to 350 cells per hour.
units.rationale: Quantifies the system’s processing speed under varying concentrations.

units.title: Low‑input library quality benchmark
units.text: We processed cell numbers of between 50 and 200 cells, of which 74.9% (s.d. ±10.7%) of input cells had more than 500 unique molecular identifiers (UMIs) per cell (Fig. 1j).
units.rationale: Demonstrates library complexity achieved with very few input cells.
